title.narrative: She Leads Kenya: Meaningful participation of GYW in formal/ informal institutions in a just/ inclusive environment

description.narrative: The project will promote institutionalization of meaningful participation of GYW in formal and informal institutions in a just and inclusive environment for promoting gender equity and equality. The project will ensure that GYW are; included in all their diversity, that they have urgency to challenge negative social gender norms, are equipped with resources and advocacy spaces to influence decisions and responsive policies that meet their needs, have ownership of initiatives by and for GYW in communities and have enhanced ability to hold duty bearers accountable.

title.narrative: A community with transformed social norms enabling GYW to challenge (discriminatory) gender norms in Kwale County by 2025

description.narrative: A community with transformed social norms enabling GYW to challenge (discriminatory) gender norms in Kwale County by 2025

title.narrative: Number of individuals (disaggregated by type, age and gender) with improved attitudes and practices towards GYWÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â¢ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ã‚Â¬ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â‚¬Å¾Ã‚Â¢s voice, agency, leadership and representative participation in decision-making processes

description.narrative: Number of individuals (disaggregated by type, age and gender) with improved attitudes and practices towards GYWÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â¢ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ã‚Â¬ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â‚¬Å¾Ã‚Â¢s voice, agency, leadership and representative participation in decision-making processes

comment.narrative: From Year 1 activity implementation, through the formation of The Influential leaders' advisory board, this has proven to be an effective platform, especially in strengthening collaborative efforts in the community in addressing and challenging Harmful Social norms through advocating for positive social norms. As well as creating spaces for GYWs to be meaningfully engaged in community engagements. In addition, the board supports in mobilization and facilitation of community forums. Furthermore, The GYW formed a social audit team to voice their needs and concerns regarding the delivery and quality of public services. The team thus developed a social accountability tool that was utilized in auditing the GBV referral pathway.;

title.narrative: Capacity building sessions held with influential community leaders, male champions, GYW feminists, community activists and media personnel through sensitization, coaching, training, mentoring, and their facilitation as community change agents.

description.narrative: Capacity building sessions held with influential community leaders, male champions, GYW feminists, community activists and media personnel through sensitization, coaching, training, mentoring, and their facilitation as community change agents.

title.narrative: Number of targeted community change agents trained on their role on influencing social and gender norms.

description.narrative: Number of targeted community change agents trained on their role on influencing social and gender norms.

comment.narrative: Most capacity building activities were conducted in Quarter 2 and 3 in line with the catch up plan. The additional 160 community agents were the pending capacity buildings to meet the target. Activity 1.2.4 was to be incurred in Quarter 3 but implemented in quarter 4 hence the high budget percentage.;

NAYA held a meeting with 29 (18 female and 11 male) community activists from the 3 sub counties on 15/6/2021 and trained them on their role in influencing social and gender norms. The training focused on understanding norms, clarifying on positive and negative norms, opportunities for change and how CAs can support advocacy and mobilization. NAYA did not spend on staff costs for 2 associates for April due to late recruitment and contract signing. NAYA also did not spend on admin costs for 2 months due to delay in kickoff and office identification. Activity 1.2.1 was also adjusted to July in the catch up plan. The activity will be implemented in July and reported on in the next quarter. The completion of the activity will reduce the underspent.;

Output 1:2: The target was not met because activity 1:2:4 was adjusted to Q4 in the catch-up plan . In activity 1:2:3 , 31 influential leaders who had been mobilized did not attend the forum . Activity 1:2:4 has been scheduled for October and the 31 leaders not met will be engaged in October. The over-expenditure was as a result of the implementation of activity 1.2.1 inline with the catch-up plan.;

The project met the target by sensitizing 90 influential leaders and 10 Kaya on gender norms, how existing practices have limited GYW potential and how they can support adoption of positive norms that encourages and promotes GYW participation. The target in the result framework was 100. The budget was fully utilized as planned.;

title.narrative: Capacity strengthening of local CSOs, CSO networks and civil society on areas identified jontly. Further, adopt an intersectional approach which will be applied to acknowledge that GYW in all their diversity often experience multiple forms of oppression, discrimination and exclusion inorder to strengthen civil society to have the will and capacity to enhance the preconditions necessary for GYW-led groupsÃƒÆ’Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â´ (formal and informal including individual feminists) strengthening and resourcing i.e have flexible funding model to resource GYW -led groups and feminists, provide mentorship and technical support.

description.narrative: Capacity strengthening of local CSOs, CSO networks and civil society on areas identified jontly. Further, adopt an intersectional approach which will be applied to acknowledge that GYW in all their diversity often experience multiple forms of oppression, discrimination and exclusion inorder to strengthen civil society to have the will and capacity to enhance the preconditions necessary for GYW-led groupsÃƒÆ’Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ãƒâ€šÃ‚Â´ (formal and informal including individual feminists) strengthening and resourcing i.e have flexible funding model to resource GYW -led groups and feminists, provide mentorship and technical support.

title.narrative: Number of CSOs trained in engagement with youth

description.narrative: Number of CSOs trained in engagement with youth

comment.narrative: Activities in this output not due for reporting;

Activity 2.2.1 ( capacity building of civil society) was held with 30 representative from 30 entities thereby achieving the output target .The Civil society were drawn from different sectors i.e 16 on Human Right , 3 on SRHR, 7 on GBV ,1 on Key Population Groups and 3 on Empowerment. Activity 2.2.2 was scheduled for Q4 , however it was brought forward in line with the acceleration plan. Thus the over expenditure .The total expense includes cost for Activity 2.3.2 inline with the PFR.;

The activities contributing to the output were not scheduled for the Quarter hence the zero in the output. 7 NAYA staff participated in the Project kick off meeting for TdH NL partners to reflect on the project implementation status and opportunities for improving partnerships, compliance, and success in 2022. NAYA had envisioned to conduct capacity building for staff on Feminism. This activity planning and preparation for training materials took longer than expected due to preparation of content and scheduling challenges for staff involved. The activity will be conducted on 5th & 6th April. The other reason for the underspent is because NAYA had budgeted to support Kwale staff for 5 nights for Kick Off but accommodated them for 3 nights as the event took 2 days.;

The activities under this output were largely implemented in Quarter 3. Activity 2.2.1 had a sub component of national capacity building which was implemented in the Quarter. GYWs representatives from the 21 clubs were trained on advocacy and leadership. The low budget spend is because NAYA did not implement Activity 2.2.2 and 2.2.3 in the Quarter. The two activities were fully implemented in Quarter 3 in line with the catch-up plan.;

title.narrative: Civil Society in Kwale County, supports GYW to collectively participate and influence decisions at County and national level by 2025

description.narrative: Civil Society in Kwale County, supports GYW to collectively participate and influence decisions at County and national level by 2025

title.narrative: Number of CSOs/CSO networks with increased GYW representation in active membership and/or leadership.

description.narrative: Number of CSOs/CSO networks with increased GYW representation in active membership and/or leadership.

comment.narrative: Following engagements with the project four (4) organizations namely; Kesho Kenya, Girl Child Network (GCN), Tiwi Child Network and COVAW have strengthened meaningful and inclusive participation of GYWs .By providing technical support and resources for Public Participation and engaging the GYW as community facilitators to advocate on SRHR issues at the community level .;

In 2021, NAYA was admitted as a member into the Kwale Child Rights Network, a network of civil society advocating for child rights and GYW rights. The project leveraged on this platform and collaborated with other civil society to identify opportunities for joint advocacy. The network held a meeting to discuss meaningful GYW engagement and opportunities for strengthening GYW engagement. The network identified other organizations working on GYW issues and incorporated them into the network. This network also updated each other on ongoing activities and engagements and opportunities for GYWs to engage in civil society discussions and in advocacy. The network developed a joint action plan for advocacy and GYW engagement that will be tracked and reported on in upcoming quarters.;

title.narrative: Collaborate with relevant government ministries and departments through capacity building and technical support on legal and policy frameworks, input on gender related matters and new knowledge and information.

description.narrative: Collaborate with relevant government ministries and departments through capacity building and technical support on legal and policy frameworks, input on gender related matters and new knowledge and information.

title.narrative: Number of government officials collaborating with She Leads on gender and inclusion

description.narrative: Number of government officials collaborating with She Leads on gender and inclusion

comment.narrative: NAYA capacity built 32 government officers thus meeting the output target. Budget line for admin and overhead was not fully utilized hence the low budget.;
No activity was conducted in the output and no budget spent as it is scheduled for upcoming quarter;
The activities under these strategies are not due for reporting. The activity is scheduled for Q3 in the results framework. However, budget was allocated for Q2.;
Under output 3:2 activity 3:3:1 is indicated as activity 3:2:4 in the budget and thus the over expenditure;

title.narrative: Conduct a mapping exercise (identifying social norms for influencing,data on effects of negative social norms, understanding different cultures, structures and infuencers to be engaged); build the capacity of GYW groups and feminists organisations on effective gathering and use of data for advocacy, whilst ensuring the inclusion of marginalized girls in all their diversities. Additionally, create and support platforms, avenues and safe spaces for linking, learning and networking by the GYW groups, Feminists youth-led organizations and CSO partners at various levels.

description.narrative: Conduct a mapping exercise (identifying social norms for influencing,data on effects of negative social norms, understanding different cultures, structures and infuencers to be engaged); build the capacity of GYW groups and feminists organisations on effective gathering and use of data for advocacy, whilst ensuring the inclusion of marginalized girls in all their diversities. Additionally, create and support platforms, avenues and safe spaces for linking, learning and networking by the GYW groups, Feminists youth-led organizations and CSO partners at various levels.

title.narrative: Number of linking and learning sessions undertaken by the GYW groups, Feminists youth-led organizations and CSO partners at various levels.

description.narrative: Number of linking and learning sessions undertaken by the GYW groups, Feminists youth-led organizations and CSO partners at various levels.

comment.narrative: 2 exchange visits were previously conducted in Quarter 3. 2 exchange visits were conducted in the quarter thus meeting the target of 4. The low budget percentage is as a result of the mismatch between the budget and the results framework numbering. As per the budget, the output only had activity 2.3.2 (consultative meeting) that was implemented in Quarter 3. The costs incurred under this output is for administration.;

4 linking and learning sessions were undertaken by the GYW groups, Feminists youth-led organizations and civil society at the village , community , county and inter-county . These were 2 exchange visits within the 3 sub-counties of Kwale and 1 inter-county exchange forum with Mombasa GYW and 1 quarterly review meeting with GYW . The total expense includes cost for Activity 2.5.1 inline with the PFR.;

The output indicator is measuring the mapping exercise that is yet to be conducted. The mapping exercise was categorized as a joint activity. The specific projects in the counties are currently waiting for mapping tools, procedures and parameters from a national consultant who is yet to be recruited. This delay has been discussed at the Country Network and a roadmap for fast tracking developed. Activity has been scheduled for Q3.;
The output is a 2021 output;

title.narrative: Consultative and sensitization meetings at County level held with targeted government representatives (decision makers, policy makers and duty bearers) from key line ministries and departments (aligned to the GYW priorities) to identify gender champions, to lobby for their support, and ensure access to technocrats and other allies in government.

description.narrative: Consultative and sensitization meetings at County level held with targeted government representatives (decision makers, policy makers and duty bearers) from key line ministries and departments (aligned to the GYW priorities) to identify gender champions, to lobby for their support, and ensure access to technocrats and other allies in government.

title.narrative: Number of national government officials reached by L&A on importance of GYW participation in political institution

description.narrative: Number of national government officials reached by L&A on importance of GYW participation in political institution

comment.narrative: A dialogue session was held with 12 MCAs ( 7 Female and 5 Male) drawn from the gender and liaison committees . 5 members who were mobilized sent last minute regrets due to other an abrupt gubernatorial functions hence the low target and under-expenditure . The project team has planned to conduct a meeting with the key leaders who were unable to attend the meeting in October.;

NAYA didnÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â¢ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ã‚Â¬ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â‚¬Å¾Ã‚Â¢t spend on staff costs for 1 month due to late recruitment. NAYA held an inception meeting with 16 national and county government officials (14 male and 2 female) to introduce the Programme, the project and its objectives and NAYA and the partnership with TdH. The CEC Social Services welcomed the project to the county and committed to support the project and include NAYA and GYW in TWGs. 14 officials including Members of the county assembly sent their apologies due to an abrupt meeting and the budget process. This impacted on the target and expenditure. NAYA has planned another inception meeting with them in July and August.;

NAYA held dialogue session with 14 women leaders representing different departments. 2 GYWs representatives were engaged in the session. The session discussed the role of women leaders in addressing GYW issues and being reliable champions. The women leaders committed to fast-track the adoption of the Kwale SGBV Bill (2018) and to engage in the Girl Dialogue Forums (GDF) to mentor and support GYWs. NAYA held a meeting with 8 government officials to plan for the International WomenÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â¢ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ã‚Â¬ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â‚¬Å¾Ã‚Â¢s Day. The activity was scheduled for Quarter 4 2022. This contributed to surpassing the target and the budget. The activity was conducted in Q1 2022 because the county requested for the meeting early to prepare for the International WomenÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â¢ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ã‚Â¬ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â‚¬Å¾Ã‚Â¢s Day which was critical and timebound.;

The activities conducted under this output were follow up of activities previously implemented in Quarter 2 and 3. The output targets and budgets are high because they were to be conducted in the previous quarters.;

description.narrative: Number of local leaders reached by L&A on importance of GYW participation in political institutions

comment.narrative: Activities for this output are not due for reporting;
Activity 1.3.2 was to be conducted in Quarter 3. However, the activity was conducted in Quarter 4 hence the high budget percentage.;

Activity 1:3:2 was rescheduled to September in the adjusted plan. However, the dialogue was not conducted since Activity 1:2:3 ( Sensitization, was targeting the same stakeholders and might have led to stakeholders fatigue , the activity has been scheduled for October.;
No activity was conducted in the output and no budget spent as it is scheduled for upcoming quarter;

title.narrative: Engage in strategic partnerships targeting traditional and mainstream media (including i.e. print, digital, electronic media including art and theatre) to highlight the impact of negative social gender norm and enhance public awareness in support of girls agency and social change.

description.narrative: Engage in strategic partnerships targeting traditional and mainstream media (including i.e. print, digital, electronic media including art and theatre) to highlight the impact of negative social gender norm and enhance public awareness in support of girls agency and social change.

title.narrative: Number of (social) media campaigns on impact of negative social gender norms on GYW supported by She Leads partners.

description.narrative: Number of (social) media campaigns on impact of negative social gender norms on GYW supported by She Leads partners.

comment.narrative: NAYA conducted one social media campaign in the quarter thus achieving the indicator target. The campaign was on the DAC and reached 34,788. It was not possible to get gender disaggregation from the analytics report. However, NAYA did not implement activity 1.4.2. The activity was adjusted to Q3 in the catch up plan. This was necessitated by delays in project set up including on boarding of project team. The co creation has been planned for July.;

NAYA conducted one social media campaign on the 16 Days of Activism thereby meeting the output target. The high budget percentage is due to procurement of banner in line with activity 1.4.2 that was budgeted for in the previous quarter and the commemoration of additional international day (the Human Rights Day) that was critical but not planned for in the work plan.;

The project supported GYWs to participate in social media campaign commemorating the International Women's Day. This was identified as key day to commemorate even though it had not been budgeted for. The project also held virtual and physical co-creation sessions. However, the budget for co-creation was not fully utilized as the samples provided by the vendor selected did not meet internal quality checks and a repeat procurement process initiated.;

Two social media campaigns were conducted during the International Youth Week , One radio show conducted at Radio Taifa , One International Day commemorated ( International Youth Day) and co-creation sessions held with 315 GYWs thus meeting the target. However the expenditure at 55.35% as the service providers have not yet been fully paid for printing services. This will be done upon the completion of the printing and production processes.;

title.narrative: Engagements with key community stakeholders utilizing the SASA Approach to facilitate a champions driven four-phased process of reflection and social norm change in their communities to support actions for social change.

description.narrative: Engagements with key community stakeholders utilizing the SASA Approach to facilitate a champions driven four-phased process of reflection and social norm change in their communities to support actions for social change.

title.narrative: Number of individuals (disaggregated by type, age and gender) reached through awareness raising sessions

description.narrative: Number of individuals (disaggregated by type, age and gender) reached through awareness raising sessions

comment.narrative: 21 forums were conducted in Quarter 2 reaching a total of 1894 thereby surpassing the targets .This was due to the accelerated implementation plan and to ensure effective programme entry. During the programme entry meetings the targeted numbers of stakeholders were not reached, as a result another entry meeting was held with the stakeholders in Q3 ,which over-ceded the target numbers leading to over-expenditure in facilitating the meeting.;

All the activities under the outputs were conducted. The total output target was met in Quarter 2 when NAYA conducted community dialogues in 21 villages and met 1894 community members. NAYA met 500 more people in quarter 4 through an additional forum that was conducted with savings realized from previous community dialogues that reached 1894..;

NAYA conducted community dialogues in 21 villages and met the targets for the output. The overachievement is because NAYA fast-tracked the dialogues as per the catch-up plan. The numbers met include the targets for Q3 as well. The forums had 1327 females and 567 males and 18 PWDs. The dialogues explored the understanding of norms, existing norms, the effects of these norms and the role of each individual in advancing GYW rights including participation. NAYA will continue engaging the community leaders to reinforce the key messages and track the commitments. NAYA did not spend on staff costs for associates for March as budgeted for due to late recruitment and contract signing. Two activities (1.1.5, 1.1.3) were adjusted to July in the catch up and Implementation is currently ongoing.;

The project held a community dialogue with 2188 community members and conducted a GirlÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â¢ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ã‚Â¬ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â‚¬Å¾Ã‚Â¢s Dialogue Forum with 631 girls. These two activities contributed to a total of 2819 individual reached. This surpassed the target of 2700. This was because the project worked with with girls, community activists and influential leaders to mobilize participants and facilitate sessions. The influential leaders also used their own meetings to mobilize for the dialogue. There was an under expenditure due to savings in 1.1.1 and 1.1.6 where the staff got reduced prices from transport providers.;

title.narrative: Government institutions in Kwale County create opportunities and spaces that enhance meaningful participation of GYW at County and national levels by 2025

description.narrative: Government institutions in Kwale County create opportunities and spaces that enhance meaningful participation of GYW at County and national levels by 2025

title.narrative: Number of formal institutions with increased meaningful participation and representation of GYW

description.narrative: Number of formal institutions with increased meaningful participation and representation of GYW

comment.narrative: The project documented key signs of change. Following engagements with key women leaders, they committed to fast-track the adoption of the Kwale SGBV Bill (2018) to provide a legal framework for addressing GBV and ensuring gender equality. The social services and youth development department reiterated their commitment to support GYWs to access information and economic empowerment and development opportunities. Women Leaders (2 Members of the Kwale County Assembly and 1 Ward Administrator) committed to hold mentorship sessions with GYWs during the Girls Dialogue Forums to discuss women leadership in quarter 2. The project will track these commitments through the commitment tracker and leverage on them.;

title.narrative: Resourcing of targetted GYW-led groups (formal and informal groups and/collectives), feminists and youth-led organizations through capacity building ( training, coaching and mentorship) and allocation/access to resources (funding, equipment, technical skills and information) to facilitate and support GYW-led advocacy.

description.narrative: Resourcing of targetted GYW-led groups (formal and informal groups and/collectives), feminists and youth-led organizations through capacity building ( training, coaching and mentorship) and allocation/access to resources (funding, equipment, technical skills and information) to facilitate and support GYW-led advocacy.

title.narrative: Number of GYW networks supported

description.narrative: Number of GYW networks supported

comment.narrative: 21 clubs have been supported to access information hence the budget of 89%. Residential capacity building for GYW is yet to be conducted (planned for November) .Part of the monies allocated for activity 2.1.2 for the sub-activity on funding GYWs groups inline with accelerated implementation plan is set Q4.;

NAYA did not spend on staff costs for 2 project associates and the programme officer for two months as budgeted for due to late recruitment and contract signing. NAYA also did not absorb the administration costs for the Kwale Office for two months due to delay in hiring staff, contract signing and acquiring a girl friendly office space. Activity 2.1.2, which has the most budget, has a mismatch between the result framework and the budget. The activity is scheduled for Q3 in the results framework and was budgeted for in Q2. The procurement process for the girl friendly space is ongoing and is expected to be completed in July.;

NAYA trained GYW from 21 clubs. NAYA requested TdH NL for the postponement of activity 2.1.2 on funding 11 networks to allow for more time for proper planning, development of selection criteria and due diligence This was granted and the activity will be implemented in Quarter 1, 2022. The high budget percentage is due to staff and administration costs that were to be incurred in Quarter 3 but incurred in the Quarter.;

The activities contributing to the output target were not implemented as they were not scheduled for the Quarter. The project supported 33 GYW to get information on their advocacy. 21 GYW were supported to engage Court Magistrates and administrators from Msambweni and Kwale Law Courts. The GYW were provided information on the role of the judiciary in promoting GYW rights including access to justice, the referral process and how GYWs can engage with judiciary. 12 GYW were supported to access information on available resourcing. The additional numbers contributed to over expenditure for the quarter. This will be adjusted in subsequent quarters.;

title.narrative: The involved and engaged of GYW groups and civil society ( incl community activists, gender champions, CSO networks and media) in advocacy forums and dialogues i.e. government processes (Public participation, budget making , Policy formulation through Technical working Group), select meetings, consultations and social accountability processes to inform and influence policies and initiatives.

description.narrative: The involved and engaged of GYW groups and civil society ( incl community activists, gender champions, CSO networks and media) in advocacy forums and dialogues i.e. government processes (Public participation, budget making , Policy formulation through Technical working Group), select meetings, consultations and social accountability processes to inform and influence policies and initiatives.

title.narrative: Number of GYW supported by She Leads partners to engage in Public Participation processes at County and National Level

description.narrative: Number of GYW supported by She Leads partners to engage in Public Participation processes at County and National Level

comment.narrative: NAYA supported 41 GYW to engage in public participation in the Kwale Sexual Gender Based Violence Bill 2018 and to engage decision makers and community members on gender based violence and GYW rights. NAYA supported GYW to engage in forums close to their villages thus saving on costs and allowing more GYW to participate. There was a mismatch between the budget and result framework where activity 3.3.2 was planned for and implemented in Quarter 4 but had been budgeted for in Q3 in the approved budget. This is the reason for the slight over expenditure.;

NAYA supported 5 GYW to engage in the National Dialogue forum which was a build-up activity to the East African Community Secretary GeneralÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â¢ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ã‚Â¬ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â‚¬Å¾Ã‚Â¢s Forum. This was a critical opportunity for GYWs to engage with other GYWs and influence national conversations on the East Africa Sexual and Reproductive Health Bill. The activity was to be implemented in upcoming quarter, but the EAC SRH Bill process was identified as a critical and timebound process that the consortium needed to engage in. NAYA also held a Meeting held with 30 civil society, 2 GYWs, and 1 CA to discuss key issues affecting GYWs in Kwale, the scope of the civil society areas and opportunities for joint advocacy. The meeting identified key advocacy opportunities and developed clear follow up mechanisms.;
NAYA surpassed the target ( supporting 34 GYWs against the target of 30 GYWs) .The project team has planned to engage more GYWs in Quarter 4 and utilize the unspent resources.;

ThereÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â¢ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â‚¬Å¡Ã‚Â¬ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â‚¬Å¾Ã‚Â¢s a mismatch for Activity 3.3.3 between the result framework and the budget. The activity is scheduled for Q3 in the results framework and was budgeted for in Q2. NAYA has planned the activity for July.;

comment.narrative: 10 civil society entities collaborated with NAYA in capacity building GYW, joint advocacy and movement building. 5 institutions (Youth Officer, Gender Department and Health Department, Children's department and County Commissioner) have involved GYW in planning key events and suported their advocacy wants.;
These activities leading to this indicators have not been implemented yet.;

comment.narrative: 6 GYWs with disabilities were engaged in key activities. No additional budget was utilized as this was linked to the specific activity budgets;
The project engaged 9 GYWs with disability through capacity building, access to information and supported advocacy initiatives.;
These activities leading to this indicators have not been implemented yet.;

title.narrative: "Power dynamics: Partnership relations in the She Leads consortium are valued as being 'deciding' (partners make final decisions)."

description.narrative: "Power dynamics: Partnership relations in the She Leads consortium are valued as being 'deciding' (partners make final decisions)."

title.narrative: PD.1 Number of partners that feel that in the She Leads consortium partners make final decisions

description.narrative: PD.1 Number of partners that feel that in the She Leads consortium partners make final decisions

comment.narrative: Power dynamics was discussed during the annual outcome harvesting meeting. The consortium reflected on how decisions are currently being made and how this can be strengthened to ensure equal decision making and address power dynamics. The Country Network and Steering Committee provided opportunities for equal decision making and continuous opportunities to reflect on power dynamics and She Leads values. NAYA held a review meeting with Community Activists and used the Girl Dialogue Forums with girls to discuss the power dynamics in the project. This discussion reflected on what was going on well, what was not going on well and opportunities for strengthening meaningful engagement. The project also conducted an FGD with GYWs to discuss how an equal partnership would look like.;

title.narrative: PD.2 Number of GYW-led groups and local CSOs that feel they have influence in the She Leads programme, including final decisions making process

description.narrative: PD.2 Number of GYW-led groups and local CSOs that feel they have influence in the She Leads programme, including final decisions making process

comment.narrative: The project is yet to engage;

title.narrative: "Safeguarding: Safe involvement to the She Leads Programme is ensured for project target groups and an enabling environment is created."

description.narrative: "Safeguarding: Safe involvement to the She Leads Programme is ensured for project target groups and an enabling environment is created."

title.narrative: Percentage of GYW involved in the programme who have knowledge, access to and trust in the reporting mechanisms to report safeguarding concerns

description.narrative: Percentage of GYW involved in the programme who have knowledge, access to and trust in the reporting mechanisms to report safeguarding concerns

comment.narrative: All the 420 GYW engaged from the 21 clubs project have been trained on their rights, safeguarding, possible safeguarding issues, how to minimize exposure and the reporting mechanisms for safeguarding issue.;

All the GYW engaged in the project have been sensitized on safeguarding, their rights, their role in the programme and channels for reporting on any violations or safeguarding concerns. Project staff do a recap in every activity and factor in safeguarding in activity planning. No additional budget was utilized as this was linked to the specific activity budgets.;

NAYA held dialogues with 271 girls (Activity 1.2.2: Support Capacity Building and Mentorship of GYW and young women feminists and Activists). The forum discussed safeguarding and key safeguarding issues and risks and how to address and report. NAYA sensistized GYW on safeguarding as it is a critical component of the program. All NAYA activities involving GYW and children will discuss safeguarding, explain rights and how to seek help. However, NAYA is yet to establish to what extent the GYW have trust in the reporting mechanisms.;

title.narrative: "Sustainability: Lasting results of the She Leads programme that goes beyond its implementation"

description.narrative: "Sustainability: Lasting results of the She Leads programme that goes beyond its implementation"

comment.narrative: These activities have not been implemented yet.;

title.narrative: SU.2 Percentage of supported individuals demonstrating improved levels of engagement with and influence over decision makers.

description.narrative: SU.2 Percentage of supported individuals demonstrating improved levels of engagement with and influence over decision makers.

comment.narrative: 21 GYW were actively engaged decision makers including women leaders, local administration and gender department and successfully secured key commitments.;
THe project has been conducting entry meetings. NAYA expects to report on this indicator in the coming quarters after several activities including direct enaggement;
